title: 2000 Summer Olympics Parade of Nations
text:
During the Parade of Nations portion of the <a href="2000%20Summer%20Olympics%20opening%20ceremony">2000 Summer Olympics opening ceremony</a>, athletes from each country participating in the Olympics paraded in the arena, preceded by their flag. The flag was borne by a sportsperson from that country chosen either by the <a href="National%20Olympic%20Committee">National Olympic Committee</a> or by the athletes themselves to represent their country.
Parade order.
As the nation of the <a href="1896%20Summer%20Olympics">first</a> modern <a href="Olympic%20Games">Olympic Games</a>, <a href="Greece">Greece</a> entered the stadium first; whereas, the host nation of <a href="Australia%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics">Australia</a> marched last. Other countries entered in alphabetical order in the language of the host country (<a href="English%20language">English</a>), according with tradition and <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">IOC</a> guidelines.
Whilst most countries entered under their <a href="List%20of%20sovereign%20states">short names</a>, a few entered under more formal or alternative names, mostly due to political and naming disputes. <a href="North%20Macedonia">Macedonia</a> entered as "Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia'" because of the <a href="Macedonia%20naming%20dispute">naming dispute with Greece</a>. The <a href="Taiwan">Republic of China</a> (commonly known as Taiwan) entered with the compromised <a href="Chinese%20Taipei">name</a> and <a href="Chinese%20Taipei%20Olympic%20flag">flag</a> of "Chinese Taipei" under T so that they did not enter together with <a href="Two%20Chinas">conflicting</a> <a href="People%27s%20Republic%20of%20China">People's Republic of China</a> (commonly known as China), which entered as the "People's Republic of China" under C. The <a href="Republic%20of%20the%20Congo">Republic of the Congo</a> entered as just "Congo" while the <a href="Democratic%20Republic%20of%20Congo">Democratic Republic of Congo</a> entered with its full name. <a href="Iran">Iran</a>, <a href="Federated%20States%20of%20Micronesia">Micronesia</a>, <a href="Republic%20of%20Moldova">Moldova</a>, <a href="Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="Brunei">Brunei</a> and the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> all entered under their formal names, respectively "Islamic Republic of Iran", "Federated States of Micronesia", "Republic of Moldova", "Lao People's Democratic Republic", "Brunei Darussalam" and "United States of America".
A record of 199 nations entered the stadium with the exception of <a href="Islamic%20Emirate%20of%20Afghanistan%20%281996%E2%80%932001%29">Afghanistan</a>, a nation banned by the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">IOC</a> in 1999 because of the extremist rule of the <a href="Taliban">Taliban</a>'s oppression on women and its sports. The parade of nations also featured a unified entrance by the athletes of the North and South Korea, holding a specially designed <a href="unification%20flag">unification flag</a>: a white background flag with a blue map of the Korean peninsula; however, the two teams competed separately. Four athletes from <a href="East%20Timor">East Timor</a> marched directly in the opening ceremonies as "<a href="Individual%20Olympic%20Athletes%20at%20the%202000%20Summer%20Olympics">Individual Olympic Athletes</a>" before the host nation. Without the existence of the National Olympic Committee, they were allowed to compete under the <a href="Olympic%20flag">Olympic flag</a>.
Notable flag bearers in the opening ceremony featured the following athletes: windsurfer <a href="Nikolaos%20Kaklamanakis">Nikolaos Kaklamanakis</a> (Greece), Olympic beach volleyball champion <a href="Sandra%20Pires">Sandra Pires</a> (Brazil), tennis player <a href="Nicol%C3%A1s%20Mass%C3%BA">Nicolás Massú</a> (Chile), heavyweight boxing champion <a href="F%C3%A9lix%20Sav%C3%B3n">Félix Savón</a> (Cuba), long-distance runner <a href="Derartu%20Tulu">Derartu Tulu</a> (Ethiopia), sprint kayaker and five-time gold medalist <a href="Birgit%20Fischer">Birgit Fischer</a> (Germany), coxless pairs rower and double gold medalist <a href="Matthew%20Pinsent">Matthew Pinsent</a> (Great Britain), show jumper <a href="Princess%20Haya%20bint%20Al%20Hussein">Princess Haya</a> (Jordan), discus thrower and 1992 Olympic champion <a href="Romas%20Ubartas">Romas Ubartas</a> (Lithuania), dressage rider <a href="Anky%20van%20Grunsven">Anky van Grunsven</a> (Netherlands), middle-distance runner <a href="Vebj%C3%B8rn%20Rodal">Vebjørn Rodal</a> (Norway), two-time Greco-Roman wrestling champion <a href="Andrzej%20Wro%C5%84ski">Andrzej Wroński</a> (Poland), five-time rowing champion <a href="Elisabeta%20Lip%C4%83">Elisabeta Lipă</a> (Romania), four-time Olympic handballer <a href="Andrey%20Lavrov">Andrey Lavrov</a> (Russia), six-time Olympic water polo player <a href="Manuel%20Estiarte">Manuel Estiarte</a> (Spain), and basketball players <a href="Carlton%20Myers">Carlton Myers</a> (Italy) and <a href="Andrew%20Gaze">Andrew Gaze</a> (Australia).
